title: Social Media and Modern Communication
learningObjectives: Learn vocabulary related to social media platforms and online interaction
Understand the impact of social media on society and communication
Practice discussing digital citizenship and online safety
Recognize terms related to content creation and digital marketing

sections.title: The Social Media Revolution
sections.content: Social media has transformed how we communicate, share information, and connect with others. Platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, TikTok, and LinkedIn have billions of users worldwide. Understanding social media vocabulary is essential in today's digital age, whether for personal use, professional networking, or business marketing. This lesson explores the language of social media, its benefits and challenges, and how to navigate the digital world responsibly.

sections.title: Social Media Platforms and Features
sections.content: Different platforms serve different purposes. Facebook connects friends and family through 'posts', 'photos', and 'status updates'. Instagram focuses on visual content - 'photos' and 'videos', with 'stories' that disappear after 24 hours. Twitter uses short 'tweets' (messages) with 'hashtags' (#) to categorize topics. TikTok features short-form videos. LinkedIn is for professional networking. Common features across platforms: 'like' or 'react' to content, 'comment' to respond, 'share' or 'retweet' to spread content, 'follow' users you're interested in, 'tag' people in posts, and send 'direct messages' (DMs) privately. Your 'profile' shows your information and content. 'Notifications' alert you to activity.

sections.title: Creating and Sharing Content
sections.content: 'Content creators' or 'influencers' produce material for audiences. They 'post' regularly to maintain 'engagement' - likes, comments, and shares. 'Viral' content spreads rapidly across the internet. 'Algorithms' determine what content users see in their 'feed' or 'timeline'. 'Hashtags' help content reach wider audiences. 'Stories' provide temporary, casual updates. 'Live streaming' broadcasts video in real-time. 'Captions' accompany visual content. 'Filters' and 'editing tools' enhance photos and videos. Building a 'following' or 'audience' takes consistent, quality content. 'Analytics' track performance metrics like 'reach', 'impressions', and 'engagement rate'.

sections.title: Social Media's Impact and Challenges
sections.content: Social media offers benefits: staying connected, accessing information, building communities, and business opportunities. However, challenges exist. 'Cyberbullying' harms people online. 'Misinformation' and 'fake news' spread quickly. 'Privacy concerns' arise from data collection. 'Addiction' to social media affects mental health. 'FOMO' (fear of missing out) creates anxiety. 'Echo chambers' expose users only to similar viewpoints. 'Trolls' post inflammatory content. 'Doomscrolling' means endlessly consuming negative news. Balance is crucial - set time limits, verify information before sharing, protect privacy, and remember that online personas don't show complete reality.

sections.title: Social Media Conversations
sections.content:
Example 1: DISCUSSING USAGE - 'I spend too much time scrolling through Instagram. I need to limit my screen time.'

Example 2: CONTENT CREATION - 'I'm trying to grow my following on TikTok by posting daily videos with trending hashtags.'

Example 3: PRIVACY CONCERN - 'I'm worried about my privacy. I've adjusted my settings to limit who can see my posts.'

Example 4: MISINFORMATION - 'Don't believe everything you see online. Always check sources before sharing news.'

sections.title: Digital Citizenship
sections.content: Social media is a powerful tool that requires responsible use. Key vocabulary includes platform names, features (post, like, share, follow), and concepts (viral, algorithm, influencer). Be a good 'digital citizen': think before you post, respect others, verify information, protect your privacy, and maintain healthy boundaries. Remember that social media shows curated versions of reality - don't compare your life to others' highlight reels. Use these platforms to connect meaningfully, learn, and share positively. Balance online and offline life for better well-being.

keyVocabulary.definition: A person with the power to affect others' purchasing decisions or opinions
keyVocabulary.example: Many brands partner with influencers for marketing campaigns.

keyVocabulary.definition: Content that spreads rapidly and widely across the internet
keyVocabulary.example: Her video went viral and got millions of views.

keyVocabulary.definition: A set of rules that determines what content users see
keyVocabulary.example: The algorithm shows you posts based on your interests.

keyVocabulary.definition: Interaction with content through likes, comments, and shares
keyVocabulary.example: High engagement rates indicate popular content.

keyVocabulary.definition: A word or phrase preceded by # to categorize content
keyVocabulary.example: Use relevant hashtags to increase your post's visibility.

keyVocabulary.definition: Bullying that takes place online or through digital devices
keyVocabulary.example: Schools are working to prevent cyberbullying among students.

grammarPoints.rule: Social Media Verbs and Phrasal Verbs
grammarPoints.explanation: Social media has created new verbs and uses of existing ones.
examples: post/upload - I posted a photo on Instagram.
scroll through - I was scrolling through my feed.
log in/out - Don't forget to log out of public computers.
sign up - Sign up for a new account.
check out - Check out this video I found!
commonMistakes: Using 'make' instead of 'post': 'I made a post' ❌ → 'I posted' ✓
Confusing 'follow' and 'unfollow': 'I don't follow him anymore' = 'I unfollowed him' ✓

grammarPoints.rule: Discussing Social Media Trends and Impact
grammarPoints.explanation: Use present perfect for recent trends and present continuous for ongoing situations.
examples: Social media has changed how we communicate. (impact)
More people are becoming aware of privacy issues. (trend)
TikTok has become extremely popular recently. (recent change)
I've been trying to reduce my screen time. (ongoing effort)
commonMistakes: Using simple past for ongoing relevance: 'Social media changed' vs 'has changed' (still relevant)
Forgetting continuous for temporary situations: 'I try to reduce' vs 'I'm trying to reduce' (current effort)
